the good marks, the precious jewels of
the average college student, with facility.
There is virtually no delving below the
surface necessary to spout these facts in
college's big game of memory.
At the end of four long and invariably
expensive years these machine-like minds
are graduated and go out into the world
wondering why the facts so essential in
college do them no good. Little do they
realize that in the quest for marks and
credits they have overlooked research or
extra study. This almost universal lack
of interest in research in a particular
field and its cognate subjects is without
a doubt one of the most sorrowful conditions existing in the college world today.
It is true that many men and women
are in colleges who should not be there,
for they are not really interested in getting an education. But those who are
there can do themselves and their institutions a favor by awakening to the fact
that delving below the surface of textbooks and instructors' lectures is vitally
necessary in the attainment of somewhat
of a true education.

By MILLARD LANGFELD, JR.

There are crooks and crooks, but
when they're super crooks of the variety portrayed by Herbert Marshall
and Miriam Hopkins, there's a story
in it. And it's a great story, too, as
you may readily find out by going
down to Keith's, where Ernest Lubitsch's latest farce, Trouble In
Paradise, opens today for a run of
one week.
Trouble In Paradise is an adaptation of a witty travesty on European
life by the noted Viennese playwright, Laszle Aladar, and concerns the adventures of a highly
charming (and highly light fingered) couple preying on the rich
poaching grounds of upper European society.
Enter Cupid, and the plot thickens. One of their victims turns out
to be a lovely young widow—and
what a lovely young widow can do
to even the heart of a hardened confidence man is nobody's business.
What happens? Well, it will be
there all this week for you to see.
Racketeers a la Sherlock Holmes

Quick, Watson, the needle!
Yes, sir, it's our old friend, Sherlock Holmes, back with us again,
and bigger and better than ever.
This time the great detective is up
against the biggest problem in his
checkered career—that notorious institution, the American Racketeer.
The secret sixes, and other anticriminal bodies making America an
unhealthy place for his operations,
the exponent of the pineapple and
machine gun has jumped the Atlantic to carry on in dear old London. But he hasn't reckoned with
Sherlock, Watson (and, we mustn't
forget, that old morphine needle).

DR. HUBBARD TO SPEAK
AT CARROLL CLUB
Physics Professor Chooses Science,
Idealism, And Modern
Youth As Topic
The Charles Carroll Club of the
Johns Hopkins University will be
addressed by Dr. J. C. Hubbard,
professor of physics, at its meeting
Sunday, November 13, at 2:30 in
Levering Hall. Dr. Hubbard will
speak on "Scientific Discoveries,
Idealism, and the Spirit of Modern
Youth". This will be followed by a
discussion and refreshments.
The Charles Carroll Club was
founded in 1928. Since then it has
become an important influence on the
campus, largely through the interest
and guidance of Dr. K. F. Herzfeld, Instructor of Physics.
Its object is three-fold: to acquaint
its members with present-day religions; to interest them in new scientific adventures; and to foster social
relationship among them.

of the Johns Hopkins University,
an active member of the Central
International Relations Club of
New York City will, in several
weeks, officially announce its program and activities for the coming
year. One of the most interesting
and fascinating organizations on the
University campus it serves as bond
of friendship between the resident
and foreign students. The club convenes bi-monthly in Levering Hall
for the purpose of hearing prominent men and women throughout the
country.

own country, to learn and cultivate
an appreciation for modern art and

With the addition of twenty-five
new men, the Johns Hopkins University Band is looking forward to
one of its best years. Many men
have already availed themselves of
the free course of instruction in all
instruments, which has been inaugurated this year. Under this plan,
instruments and uniforms are supplied by the R. 0. T. C.
Real Band In Prospect

Mr. Conrad Gebelein, director of
the Band, urges those candidates
who have their own instruments to
bring them. He stated, "My desire
to see a fifty-piece Band that the
University may be proud of, will
soon be a reality."
Rehearsals are held at the Barn
every Monday and Friday at 4:00
p. m. Students at the University
who play any of the stringed instruments are invited to join Mr. Gebelein's Musical Club groups, which
meet for rehearsal on Thursday
nights at 9 o'clock, in Room B, Levering Hall.
Rufus M. Roll is the student
leader of the Band.

the good marks, the precious jewels of
the average college student, with facility.
There is virtually no delving below the
surface necessary to spout these facts in
college's big game of memory.
At the end of four long and invariably
expensive years these machine-like minds
are graduated and go out into the world
wondering why the facts so essential in
college do them no good. Little do they
realize that in the quest for marks and
credits they have overlooked research or
extra study. This almost universal lack
of interest in research in a particular
field and its cognate subjects is without
a doubt one of the most sorrowful conditions existing in the college world today.
It is true that many men and women
are in colleges who should not be there,
for they are not really interested in getting an education. But those who are
there can do themselves and their institutions a favor by awakening to the fact
that delving below the surface of textbooks and instructors' lectures is vitally
necessary in the attainment of somewhat
of a true education.

By MILLARD LANGFELD, JR.

There are crooks and crooks, but
when they're super crooks of the variety portrayed by Herbert Marshall
and Miriam Hopkins, there's a story
in it. And it's a great story, too, as
you may readily find out by going
down to Keith's, where Ernest Lubitsch's latest farce, Trouble In
Paradise, opens today for a run of
one week.
Trouble In Paradise is an adaptation of a witty travesty on European
life by the noted Viennese playwright, Laszle Aladar, and concerns the adventures of a highly
charming (and highly light fingered) couple preying on the rich
poaching grounds of upper European society.
Enter Cupid, and the plot thickens. One of their victims turns out
to be a lovely young widow—and
what a lovely young widow can do
to even the heart of a hardened confidence man is nobody's business.
What happens? Well, it will be
there all this week for you to see.
Racketeers a la Sherlock Holmes

Quick, Watson, the needle!
Yes, sir, it's our old friend, Sherlock Holmes, back with us again,
and bigger and better than ever.
This time the great detective is up
against the biggest problem in his
checkered career—that notorious institution, the American Racketeer.
The secret sixes, and other anticriminal bodies making America an
unhealthy place for his operations,
the exponent of the pineapple and
machine gun has jumped the Atlantic to carry on in dear old London. But he hasn't reckoned with
Sherlock, Watson (and, we mustn't
forget, that old morphine needle).

DR. HUBBARD TO SPEAK
AT CARROLL CLUB
Physics Professor Chooses Science,
Idealism, And Modern
Youth As Topic
The Charles Carroll Club of the
Johns Hopkins University will be
addressed by Dr. J. C. Hubbard,
professor of physics, at its meeting
Sunday, November 13, at 2:30 in
Levering Hall. Dr. Hubbard will
speak on "Scientific Discoveries,
Idealism, and the Spirit of Modern
Youth". This will be followed by a
discussion and refreshments.
The Charles Carroll Club was
founded in 1928. Since then it has
become an important influence on the
campus, largely through the interest
and guidance of Dr. K. F. Herzfeld, Instructor of Physics.
Its object is three-fold: to acquaint
its members with present-day religions; to interest them in new scientific adventures; and to foster social
relationship among them.

of the Johns Hopkins University,
an active member of the Central
International Relations Club of
New York City will, in several
weeks, officially announce its program and activities for the coming
year. One of the most interesting
and fascinating organizations on the
University campus it serves as bond
of friendship between the resident
and foreign students. The club convenes bi-monthly in Levering Hall
for the purpose of hearing prominent men and women throughout the
country.

own country, to learn and cultivate
an appreciation for modern art and

With the addition of twenty-five
new men, the Johns Hopkins University Band is looking forward to
one of its best years. Many men
have already availed themselves of
the free course of instruction in all
instruments, which has been inaugurated this year. Under this plan,
instruments and uniforms are supplied by the R. 0. T. C.
Real Band In Prospect

Mr. Conrad Gebelein, director of
the Band, urges those candidates
who have their own instruments to
bring them. He stated, "My desire
to see a fifty-piece Band that the
University may be proud of, will
soon be a reality."
Rehearsals are held at the Barn
every Monday and Friday at 4:00
p. m. Students at the University
who play any of the stringed instruments are invited to join Mr. Gebelein's Musical Club groups, which
meet for rehearsal on Thursday
nights at 9 o'clock, in Room B, Levering Hall.
Rufus M. Roll is the student
leader of the Band.
